Postings.Text:
Simon Gerrans: GreenEDGE
‘I’m just really rpat for all the supporters of GreenEDGE, for everyone who has backed the team from such an early stage and all the guys who have been channelling in since the team started, as well as all the riders that signed on. It’s just so nice to have our first victory at our first world outing in Australia. This really takes the pressure off (for the teams’ first outing). Often that first victory for a new team is the hardest one to get and we’ve got in our first outing, so it really is a dream start and I think this will create a great momentum for the year to come. ‘I’ll be wearing this jersey with pride all year long. It is such an honour to be the Australian champion and also to be part of the GreenEDGE Team.’

Alejandro Valverde: Movistar Team
“I am very happy with finishing second in the Santos Tour Down Under. The outcome is much better than I expected when I came to Australia. Today was a super fast stage with a bit of wind that made it even more difficult. I’m very happy.”

Eddy Merckx:
“It was a great race and I will be thanking everybody, everything was great”

Jan Bakelants: RadioShack-Nissan-Trek
“It’s a nice extra; I didn’t expect it and I knew this morning I could move up one place if I took a bonus sprint. I knew it would be difficult and I saw the opportunity to go. There was a large gap and I was going pretty fast and was secure to take the sprint then I waited for Cameron [Meyer] and he came with me. It was absolutely a great start to the year.”

Robbie McEwen – GreenEdge Cycling Team 
“I’m just really happy and proud to be part of this team here at the Santos Tour Down Under. I’m not retiring today, that was my last Aussie race officially, but the season’s not done. I am still going to race for another four months after this. It’s a fantastic way to go out as far as Australia racing is concerned. I joined the team and was really excited about being a part of the GreenEDGE project racing in an Aussie team, our national team. It was all about winning the jersey and that’s the success for the team, it feels like a personal win to be a part of it”.

Edvald Boasson Hagen: Sky Procycling
“I got the jersey but I would like to be more up in the final stage, but I managed to keep the jersey so that’s a good thing. It’s an early start to the season and to be on top form now is difficult.I’m happy to be on ok form and I can still get better”.

Jens Voigt: RadioShack-Nissan-Trek 
“We like to win a team GC and on top of that we managed to place Tiago; we are pretty happy with the outcome of the race. Well, fortunately everybody knows what they’re up for and we try and stay in the air-conditioned rooms as much as possible.”

Cameron Meyer: GreenEdge Cycling Team: 
“The main goal of the day was not me, it was for Simon. I am happy with my form to date, I think I’m on the right track, I am happy with where I am at”.

Tiago Machado:
“For me, I need to say thanks to the team for the support along the week and I cannot forget the last half of the last season. Some people, my brother Johan, my personal coach, who prepared me for the beginning of the season. I look forward to the biggest bike race in the world and the rest of the season.”

Mike Turtur: Race Director
“Everyone has worked hard to present the race and the riders have done their bit. They have raced in all sorts of hard conditions and it has been an entertaining week. GreenEDGE and Simon two times winner now joins Greipel and O’Grady and a terrific start for GreenEDGE and hopefully they have a great season. Will keep working at the race and I reckon the race is equal to a lot of races in Europe at the moment. We're happy we have found our place for the first race of the season which creates a lot of interest. It's developing nicely and maintained a level that Armstrong established and we're big enough to stand on our own two feet.”

Luke Durbridge: GreenEDGE
“I can’t be happier. The teams rode really well this week, just to be a part of this is fantastic, I feel very privileged and very lucky to be a part of this team. I am a passionate Australian and to see the first Pro Tour Team for Australia win, you can’t get much better than that. I’m so stoked and looking forward to an exciting year with the team”.

Matthew Lloyd: Lampre-ISD
“We put people in the right spot at the right time. For our group, our sprinters are more focussed on the Tour De France and some of the other classics. It is remarkable our sprinters came to the SantosTour Down Under (given the time of the year) as it usually takes them a few months to line up.

Gerry Ryan: GreenEDGE owner
“It’s fantastic, it’s been a great journey and this puts the icing on the cake. We came here and didn’t have an expectation to win it, didn’t have a plan to win it but it’s nice”.

Mark Renshaw: Rabobank Cycling Team 
“It was a hard stage and I missed the break and we should have had a guy in there. It didn’t go to plan, still I can beat the best guys Mark Cavendish and Andre Griepel if a little luck goes my way. It’s good to finish the week with a second. Qatar is my next race and a good objective and I’d like to defend my title.”

Rohan Dennis: Uni SA 
“I wasn’t sure I was actually going to finish this race, I was pretty happy it slowed down, I think everybody was. With that surge at the start it almost slowed it down and made it a little bit easier towards the end”.
“I’m pretty happy, I was lucky to actually hold onto my position because of the gap of 50-100 metres on the last track”.

Matt White: GreenEDGE Manager
I certainly am [happy]. The Nationals are one thing but to win the Santos Tour Down Under with our newly crowned National Champion, we couldn’t have written a better script. [I’m] elated, just elated.

It was the G & G show in stage 6 of the Santos Tour Down Under as Simon Gerrans and Andre Greipel claimed the major honours on another hot day in the South Australian capital. The Lotto-Belisol team train set up Greipel perfectly for the sprint finish and as usual no one could go with his powerful burst in the last 200metres. Gerrans ultimately had no trouble marking Alejandro Valverde (ESP) - MOV out of the battle for Ochre as the GreenEDGE team showed aggression from the outset to make a late charge for victory by the Spaniard impossible. As soon as racing began under blue skies in 36 degree temperatures, GreenEDGE riders were involved in the all the attacks. First it was Luke Durbridge and later 2011 champion Cameron Meyer who helped keep the breaks ahead of the bunch, largely controlled by GreenEDGE. Durbridge helped take care of the first Jayco Sprint at the end of lap eight while Meyer did likewise for the 2nd Jayco sprint four laps later. Meyer also kept a watchful eye on Jan Bakelants (BEL) - RNT who as the race drew towards its climax managed to build a 50 second lead over the peloton and assume the overall race leadership on the road. But as the final lap began the lead was down to 22 seconds, and by the time the riders had reached Montefiore Hill for the last time, they’d been swallowed up and we were set for a traditional bunch sprint. Lotto-Belisol then assumed control and when Greipel kicked, he finished a length clear of Mark Renshaw (AUS) - RAB and Alessandro Petacchi (ITA) - LAM. Valverde and Gerrans finished in 25th and 27th places but more importantly at the same time which ensured Gerrans became a STDU winner for the second time after claiming his maiden victory in 2006. Only Stuart O’Grady (1999 and 2001) and Andre Greipel (2008 and 2010) had previously won two SANTOS Tours Down Under. The was the closest STDU since 2003 when that race was decided on count back after Mikel Astarloza and Lennie Lange Kristenesen were also tied on the same overall time. Gerrans and Valverde were separated by an aggregate of race positions, with Gerrans finishing in an average 17th position and Valverde 29th. Another rider to have a good day was Rohan Dennis (AUS - SA) - UNA, who watched from the relative comfort of the peloton as the breakaway riders took care of the SKODA KOM points to give him a win in that classification. Dennis also won the Cycle Instead Young Rider Classification and by finishing in 5th position on General Classification took out the Tanya Denver Memorial Award for being the highest placed South Australian rider. One of the pre race favourites Edvald Boasson Hagen (NOR) - SKY can also leave Adelaide happy with his week. EBH was seventh on the General Classification at 0:18 and winner of the Jayco Sprint Classification. About the only thing that wasn’t fast this week was the overall race speed. At just 38.7kmh it was the slowest in Santos Tour Down Under history. This was mainly due to the ferocious headwinds which caused chaos in the peloton on the first stage from Prospect to Clare. But nothing will spoil the week for GreenEDGE Cycling. Their first week as a World Tour team ended perfectly with a win in their debut race and a legion of new fans as they head to Europe for the rest of the season.

TOUR DOWN UNDER HONOUR ROLL:
Simon Gerrans victory in this year's SANTOS Tour Down Under extends the Aussies lead over the internationals after 14 editions of this great race.

Eight Aussies and six Europeans have claimed the Tour’s ultimate prize.

Three riders have now won it twice, Gerrans (2006 and 2012),Stuart O’Grady (1999 and ���01) and Andre Greipel (2008 and ‘10).
Race winners have come from eight different teams, with the ever-present AG2R leading the way---Maignan (2000), Astarloza (2003), Gerrans (2006) and Elmiger (2007).
 Team High Road/Columbia has two (Greipel), as does Credit Agricole (O’Grady).
GreenEDGE plus Aussie composite teams—Uni SA (Jonker, ‘04) and United Water (Rogers, ’02) have one each as do the US based Garmin-Cervelo (Meyer 2011), the Belgian outfit Quickstep (Davis, 2009) and Liberty Seguros Worth (Sanchez, 2005).

JOURNO POLL: Congrats to the journos who picked Simon Gerrans to win. There were seven of you so maybe that wasn't too hard, but picking a 1,2,3 for the podium proved a whole lot more difficult...in fact, impossible. Closest in correct order was Gregor Brown from Cycle Sport Magazine, one of the international writers here in Adelaide. He picked Simon Gerrans (AUS) - GEC, Edvald Boasson Hagen (NOR) - SKY and Alejandro Valverde (ESP) - MOV. Credit should also go to Val Migliaccio from the Advertiser who picked Alejandro Valverde (ESP) - MOV, Simon Gerrans (AUS) - GEC and Edvald Boasson Hagen (NOR) - SKY as his top 3. Better luck next year!

The 2012 Santos Tour Down Under will go down as the slowest in the race’s 14 year history.
The opening stage from Prospect to Clare is largely responsible for this after ferocious headwinds contained the average stage speed to just 32.7kmh
A look through the race figures show how the speeds have fluctuated from year to year.
To date, the fastest edition of the TDU was in 2004, when Patrick Jonker’s glorious final race average a massive 44.45 km/h over the 735 km route.
Prior to this year the previous slowest race was in 2001 when Stuart O’Grady’s successful tilt at a second TDU crown averaged 38.76kmh for each of the 754kms.
The full list of race times from fastest to slowest:
2004: 735km @ 44.45kmh.
2002: 733km @ 43.15kmh.
2005: 719km @ 42.92kmh.
2003: 735km @ 42.53kmh
2007: 667km @ 42.30kmh.
2010: 784km @ 42.21kmh.
2011: 749km @ 41.84kmh
2008: 782km @ 41.67kmh
2006: 685km @ 41.26kmh.
2000: 777km @ 40.82kmh.
2009: 793km @ 40.81kmh
1999: 762km @ 40.00kmh.
2001: 754km @ 38.76kmh.
2012: 803km @ 38.7kmh.

STAGE 6:

Winners time: 1:56.48
SPEED: 46.2kmh

2012 STDU 
number of starters 133.
number of finishers: 126.
total distance: 803.3km
aggregate time: 20:45.20

Race average speed:
38.7kmh

OFFICIAL RESULTS: SKODA KOM: 1:Rohan Dennis (AUS - SA) - UNA: 29pts. 2:Thomas de Gendt (BEL) - VCD: 24pts. 3:Simon Gerrans (AUS) - GEC: 24pts. 4:Tiago Machado (POR) - RNT 18pts. 5:Alejandro Valverde (ESP) - MOV: 16pts 6:Nathan Haas (AUS) - GRM 16pts. SKODA KOM Cameron Meyer (AUS) - GEC (cat 3 @ 42.5km). 1:Greg Van Avermaet (BEL) - BMC: 3pts 2:Davide Cimolai (ITA) - LAM: 2pts 3:Luke Durbridge (AUS) - GEC: 1pt SKODA KOM Robbie McEwen (AUS) - GEC (cat 3 @ 64km). 1:Cameron Meyer (AUS) - GEC: 3pts 2:Romain Sicard (FRA) - EUS: 2pts 3:Jan Bakelants (BEL) - RNT: 1pt

Andre Greipel (GER) - LTB: “What can I say? The team Lotto-Belisol has just been amazing in leading me out to my third win of the week. It looks easy but it’s not. I was nowhere in the front on GC this year but I’m happy with the sprint finishes. I always like to come to South Australia. It’s just nice to start the new season here rather than train in Europe.”

OFFICIAL RESULTS:Jayco Sprint Classifcation: 1:Edvald Boasson Hagen (NOR) - SKY: 56pts. 2:Andre Greipel (GER) - LTB: 50pts. 3: Yauheni Hutarovich (BLR) - FDJ: 39pts. 4: Mark Renshaw (AUS) - RAB: 33pts. 5: Michael Matthews (AUS) - RAB: 32pts. 6: Daniele Bennati (ITA) - RNT: 32pts 7: Alejandro Valverde (ESP) - MOV: 27pts 8: Simon Gerrans (AUS) - GEC 27pts 9: Alessandro Petacchi (ITA) - LAM 27pts 10:Oscar Freire (ESP) - KAT 25pts. JAYCO SPRINT FINISH LINE: 1: Andre Greipel (GER) - LTB 15pts 2: Mark Renshaw (AUS) - RAB 14pts 3: Alessandro Petacchi (ITA) - LAM 13pts 4: Yauheni Hutarovich (BLR) - FDJ 12pts 5: Jose Joaquin Rojas (ESP) - MOV 11pts 6: Edvald Boasson Hagen (NOR) - SKY 10pts 7: Romain Feillu (FRA) - VCD 9pts 8: Jonathan Cantwell (AUS) - SAX 8pts 9: Fabio Sabatini (ITA) - LIQ 7pts 10:Manuel Belletti (ITA) - ALM 6pts LAP 8: 1: Davide Cimolai (ITA) - LAM 5pts 2: Luke Durbridge (AUS) - GEC 3pts 3: Jack Bauer (NZL) - GRM 2pts LAP 12: 1: Jan Bakelants (BEL) - RNT 5pts 2: Cameron Meyer (AUS) - GEC 3pts 3: Jack Bauer (NZL) - GRM 2pts

Simon Gerrans (AUS) - GEC: “This is just fantastic. I can’t thank the GreenEdge team enough for this victory. We had a tough task today to control Alejandro Valverde who is a classic rider. The last lap was very fast. I had Robbie McEwen looking after me, that was pretty special since it was his last race in Australia. When I was told yesterday that I was getting the leader’s jersey, I didn’t feel any pressure at all, it was just a nice surprise. I knew it would give us a tough job for this last stage, but as it turns out, I can’t be happier. It’s an even sweeter victory than my first one here in 2006. It gives me the opportunity to thank for the first time the Ryan family and Shayne Bannan for putting this team together. It couldn’t be a better start for us.”

OFFICIAL RESULTS (selected) Stage 6: 63: Danilo Hondo (GER) - LAM @st (as winner) 64: Luis Leon Sanchez (ESP) - RAB @0:16. 126: Massimo Graziato (ITA) - LAM @5:02 DNF: Andreas Klier (GER) - GRM Arnaud Courteille (FRA) - FDJ Victor Cabedo (ESP) - EUS Pablo Urtasun (ESP) - EUS

OFFICIAL RESULTS: Stage 6: 1: Andre Greipel (GER) - LTB 2: Mark Renshaw (AUS) - RAB 3: Alessandro Petacchi (ITA) - LAM 4: Yauheni Hutarovich (BLR) - FDJ 5: Jose Joaquin Rojas (ESP) - MOV 6: Edvald Boasson Hagen (NOR) - SKY 7: Romain Feillu (FRA) - VCD 8: Jonathan Cantwell (AUS) - SAX 9: Fabio Sabatini (ITA) - LIQ 10: Manuel Belletti (ITA) - ALM @st

Santos Tour Down Under winner Simon Gerrans:
"Just fantastic. Can't thank  my team mates enough. We had a tough task today to watch Alejandro Valverde but we did a great job."

Speaking on Channel 9 after his win: Andre Greipel (GER) - LTB has this to say: "I think the team was just amazing to do what they did there. The guys made the sprint look easy and got me to the last 200m. I always like to come back here. It's just a nice place to start the season."
